categories.name: Alcohol
categories.title: What is your policy on the legal age for alcohol consumption and purchase?

questions.question: The legal age should remain 18 years old but more focus needs to be put on tackling our harmful drinking culture.
This is a conscience vote. Policy focus is on reforming alcohol laws and trading hours, and reducing alcohol-related crime.
questions.policy: Conscience vote - A type of vote where MPs are allowed to vote according to their own personal conscience rather than according to an official line of their political party.

questions.question: Raise the purchase age to 20 years old.
This policy issue is a conscience vote.
questions.policy: Conscience vote - A type of vote where MPs are allowed to vote according to their own personal conscience rather than according to an official line of their political party.

questions.question: Keep legal age at 18, but place restrictions on establishing new liquor outlets and trading hours.
Keep the legal age at 18.

categories.name: Unemployment
categories.title: What is your policy on reducing unemployment?

questions.question: Invest $1 billion into research and development to build a smart, green economy which is jobs rich and better for everyone.
0% target with a right to work; 100,000 new temp jobs. High tech jobs in a digital economy.
Create more jobs and boost incomes (wages growing faster than inflation) to reduce unemployment.
Less immigration, support regional development, more added value to our products.
Reduce unemployment to 4% within 3 years and ensure everyone under the age of 20 is in work, education or training.
Expand Maori and Pacific Trades training by having partnerships with industry and government to extend cadetships, providing work experience and formal qualifications.
questions.policy: Cadetships - A cadetship involves paid employment at the same time you are studying or training.

questions.question: Extend the 90-day trial period and introduce a low flat tax that encourages and rewards employment.
questions.policy: Flat tax - A system that applies the same tax rate to every taxpayer regardless of income bracket with no deductions or exemptions allowed.

categories.name: Climate Change
categories.title: What is your policy regarding climate change mitigation targets?

questions.question: Achieve carbon neutrality by 2050, through a carbon tax which would pay for a personal income tax-free threshold of $2000, and a 1% cut in the company tax rate.
questions.policy: Carbon neutrality - Making or resulting in no net release of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere, especially as a result of carbon offsetting. Carbon Tax - a tax on fossil fuels, intended to reduce the emission of carbon dioxide. Company Tax Rate - currently 28%.

questions.question: 100% of electricity generated from renewable sources by 2025 and replace the Emissions Trading Scheme with an Emissions Levy.
questions.policy: ETS - New Zealand Emissions Trading Scheme (NZ ETS) puts a price on emissions and therefore creates a financial incentive to change behaviours

questions.question: NZ to make a fair and affordable contribution to global emissions reduction efforts. The ETS as the most effective tool.
questions.policy: ETS - New Zealand Emissions Trading Scheme (NZ ETS) the primary tool of the govt. to reduce emissions. The NZ ETS puts a price on emissions and therefore creates a financial incentive for all New Zealanders – especially businesses and consumers – to change our behaviour.

questions.question: Establish strategies and research targets for fossil carbon reduction.
questions.policy: Fossil Carbon - Carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases generated by burning fossil fuels.

questions.question: Adopt more ambitious targets for reducing emissions and strengthen the ETS including restricting international units.
questions.policy: ETS - New Zealand Emissions Trading Scheme (NZ ETS) the primary tool of the govt. to reduce emissions. The NZ ETS puts a price on emissions and therefore creates a financial incentive for all New Zealanders – especially businesses and consumers – to change our behaviour.

questions.question: Review the ETS, invest in low emission technologies and plant more trees. Incentivise those who reduce emissions and deincentivise polluters through setting a carbon price.
questions.policy: ETS - New Zealand Emissions Trading Scheme (NZ ETS) the primary tool of the government to reduce emissions. The NZ ETS puts a price on emissions and therefore creates a financial incentive for all New Zealanders – especially businesses and consumers – to change our behaviour.

questions.question: The costs of mitigation are greater than the benefits.
questions.policy: Mitigation - The action of reducing the severity or seriousness of something.

categories.name: Education
categories.title: What is your policy on education, specifically primary and secondary school?

questions.question: Quality and free public education. Schools are community hubs focussed on what all kids need to reach their potential.
100% free, public education system, scrapping National Standards. Support capability development and pedagogical change.
questions.policy: Pedagogy - The art or profession of teaching. National Standards - The standards that students need to meet in reading, writing, and mathematics in the first eight years at school.

questions.question: $10.1 billion for childhood, primary and secondary education. Increase percentage of 18 year olds achieving NCEA level 2 to 85% by 2017.
Close Charter Schools, remove National Standards and front end the education spend on an equity basis.
questions.policy: Charter Schools - A Charter School is a school which receives public funding but operates independently. Charter Schools are an example of alternative education.  National Standards - The standards set clear expectations that students need to meet in reading, writing, and mathematics in the first eight years at school.

questions.question: Deliver 2,000 extra teachers to reduce class sizes, make digital devices affordable for Year 5-13 students, and replace school donations.
Increase the quality of, and access to, primary and secondary education for all, including supporting cultural competency and civics education.
Greater choice for parents and students. Any public school can become a Partnership School.

categories.name: Housing
categories.title: What is your policy regarding the standard of housing and its affordability?

questions.question: Introduce a warrant of fitness for rentals and the right to renew tenancies with limits on rent increases. Also introduce progressive home ownership for first home buyers.
Build 30,000 new state rental houses and introduce a warrant of fitness for rental homes. Assist low and middle income earners into home ownership.
Increasing housing supply and work with Councils, reform the RMA, and reduce building costs.
Government assistance programme for land purchase for first home buyers.
Build 100,000 affordable homes over 10 years and introduce a Health Homes Guarantee for rentals.
A warrant of fitness for all houses and introduce programmes which enable the development of social and affordable housing and housing loans for low income earners.
Local authorities should release more land for homes and reduce red-tape.

categories.name: Tax
categories.title: What is your policy on Income (PAYE) Tax?

questions.question: Develop a tax structure that promotes equality and is broad-based, treating different sources of income equally.
Introduce Capital Gains, Wealth, and Financial Transactions Taxes. Any tax cuts only for the lowest incomes.
questions.policy: Capital Gains Tax - A tax levied on profit from the sale of property or an investment. Wealth Tax - A tax levied on personal capital. Financial Transaction Tax - A financial transaction tax is a levy placed on a specific type of monetary transaction for a particular purpose.

questions.question: Three-quarters of Kiwi income earners pay a top personal tax rate of just 17.5% or less.
Everyone should pay their fair share, clamp down on tax evasion.
Introduce a Capital Gains Tax (excluding the family home) and a new progressive top tax rate of 36% on income over $150,000.
questions.policy: Capital Gains Tax - A tax levied on profit from the sale of property or an investment.

questions.question: Review tax system to ensure greater benefits to individuals rather than corporations, including no tax on first $25,000 earned and extending Tax Credit to low income families.
Introduce a low flat tax as it encourages and rewards employment.
questions.policy: Flat tax - A system that applies the same tax rate to every taxpayer regardless of income bracket with no deductions or exemptions allowed.

categories.name: Student Debt
categories.title: What is your policy regarding the future of student loans and/or allowances?

questions.question: Restore student allowance for postgrad students and introduce debt write-off.
Progressively reduce fees to zero, write-off existing student loan debt and introduce a universal student allowance.
$199m boost for tertiary education, interest free student loans and more support for low-income students.
Introduce a dollar-for-dollar repayment scheme, bonding and universal student allowance.

Review of the student support system, including allowances, loans, accommodation support and scholarships to create a system that increases access to tertiary education, that is fair, transparent and sustainable.
Reform the student loan scheme so that it is easier to borrow and pay back, potential options for debt write-off. This will give students time to get into the workforce post study before repayment.
Interest free student loans are unfair, costly to the nation and encourage over-borrowing.

categories.name: Health
categories.title: What is your policy on access to high quality and affordable health care?

questions.question: Extend free GP visits for children up to 18 years old. Focus on accessible primary healthcare.
Emphasise individual-led healthcare and cut waste. Promote a good standard of living (housing, income, work) and wellbeing.
Provide NZ with high quality healthcare by lifting spending, providing record numbers of surgeries and employing 5000 more doctors and nurses.
Focus on rural provision and how to use capacity in private providers to deliver surgery.
Make doctor visits and prescriptions free for children under 13, pregnant women, and people aged 65 and older, and extend the Care Plus program for people with long-term illnesses.
questions.policy: Care Plus - A primary health care funding initiative to support people with high health needs due to chronic conditions, acute medical or mental health needs, or terminal illness.

questions.question: Free doctors visits for children under 18, as well as promoting cultural competency and health literacy.
The health system should provide more choice for the users.

categories.name: Transport
categories.title: What is your policy on access to public transport?

questions.question: Free off-peak travel for students and invest $10billion+ in new public transport and rail over 10 years.
Smart transport solutions, promoting public transport and cycling.
All citizens to have access to public transport, a choice in mode of travel, and to help businesses choose the most efficient way of getting goods to market.
Support public transport but also recognise rural transport solutions.
Invest in modern, affordable and convenient public transport systems in our cities. This includes building the Auckland City Rail Link and funding it 50:50 with the Auckland Council.
Free travel for those over 65 years and for all students at all levels. Improve urban design so people are more likely to use public transport, walk or cycle.
Respect that private vehicles are the choice of our citizens.
